title: Lesson 7: All Together
text:
Part 1
Show me a distribution of the departure delay times by each carrier for flights that depart after 5pm






Idea for Graph

title: Lesson 7: All Together
text:
Part 2
Which airports out of JFK, LGA, & EWR have the lowest average departure delay time?


Code
flights %>% 
    filter(!is.na(dep_delay), origin %in% c('JFK', 'LGA', 'EWR')) %>% 
    group_by(origin) %>% 
    summarise(Average = mean(dep_delay)) %>% 
    knitr::kable()





origin
Average




EWR
15.10795


JFK
12.11216


LGA
10.34688

title: Lesson 8: R vs. Python
text:
In this article you will see the same analysis preformed in R & Python. Note the similarities and differences.






 










R


library(tidyverse)


dat <- read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/grades.csv")


is_math <- c("FDMAT108", "MATH101")
is_stats <- c("MATH221A", "MATH325")
is_major <- c("CIT111", "CIT225")
is_general_ed <- c("FDAMF101", "FDENG101")


dat1 <- dat %>% 
  select(!c(`Course Program`, `Catalog`, `Grade Type`)) %>% 
  filter(!str_starts(Grade, "N/A")) %>% 
  mutate(
    Grade = fct_relevel(Grade, c("A", "A-", "B+", "B", "B-", "C+", "C", "C-", "D+", "D", "D-", "F", "P", "W")), 
    Semester = fct_relevel(Semester, "WI19", "SP19", "FA19", "WI20", "SP20", "FA20", "WI21", "SP21", "FA21", "WI22", "SP22", "FA22"), 
    `Grade Points` = case_when(
      Grade == "A" ~ 4, 
      Grade == "A-" ~ 3.7, 
      Grade == "B+" ~ 3.4, 
      Grade == "B" ~ 3,
      Grade == "B-" ~ 2.7, 
      Grade == "C+" ~ 2.4,
      Grade == "C" ~ 2, 
      Grade == "C-" ~ 1.7,
      Grade == "D+" ~ 0.4, 
      Grade == "D" ~ 1,
      Grade == "D-" ~ 0.7, 
      Grade == "F" ~ 0,
      Grade == "UW" ~ 0, 
      Grade == "P" ~ NA_real_,
      Grade == "W" ~ NA_real_, 
      Grade == "I" ~ NA_real_,
      Grade == "T" ~ NA_real_, 
      Grade == "NR" ~ NA_real_), 
    Course = str_replace(Course, "-\\d\\d", ""), 
    Course = str_replace(Course, "\\W", ""), 
    is_math = case_when(Course %in% is_math ~ 1, TRUE ~ 0),
    is_stats = case_when(Course %in% is_stats ~ 1, TRUE ~ 0), 
    is_major = case_when(Course %in% is_major ~ 1, TRUE ~ 0), 
    is_general_ed = case_when(Course %in% is_general_ed ~ 1, TRUE ~ 0)
)



head(dat1)

# A tibble: 6 × 10
  Course   `Course Title` Credits Grade Semester `Grade Points` is_math is_stats
  <chr>    <chr>            <dbl> <fct> <fct>             <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl>
1 DANCE18… Social Dance,…       1 P     WI19                 NA       0        0
2 FDAMF101 American Foun…       3 A     WI19                  4       0        0
3 FDENG101 Writing & Rea…       3 A     WI19                  4       0        0
4 FDMAT108 Math for the …       3 A     WI19                  4       1        0
5 FDREL275 Teachings of …       2 A     WI19                  4       0        0
6 GS106A   College Succe…       1 A     WI19                  4       0        0
# … with 2 more variables: is_major <dbl>, is_general_ed <dbl>








Python


import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from plotnine import *
dat = pd.read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/grades.csv")


is_math = ("FDMAT108", "MATH101")
is_stats = ("MATH221A", "MATH325")
is_major = ("CIT111", "CIT225")
is_general_ed = ("FDAMF101", "FDENG101")


dat1 = (dat
    .drop(['Course Program', 'Catalog', 'Grade Type'], axis = 1)
    .query("~Grade.str.startswith('N/A')")
    .assign(
        Grade = lambda X: pd.Categorical(X.Grade, categories = ["A", "A-", "B+", "B", "B-", "C+", "C", "C-", "D+", "D", "D-", "F", "P", "W"]), 
        Semester = lambda X: pd.Categorical(X.Semester, ["WI19", "SP19", "FA19", "WI20", "SP20", "FA20", "WI21", "SP21", "FA21", "WI22", "SP22", "FA22"]),
        Grade_Points = lambda X: X['Grade'].replace({
            "A": 4, 
            "A-": 3.7,
            "B+": 3.4, 
            "B": 3,
            "B-": 2.7, 
            "C+": 2.4,
            "C": 2, 
            "C-": 1.7,
            "D+": 0.4, 
            "D": 1,
            "D-": 0.7, 
            "F": 0,
            "UW": 0, 
            "P": np.nan,
            "W": np.nan, 
            "I": np.nan,
            "T": np.nan, 
            "NR": np.nan}),
        Course = lambda X: X['Course'].replace({r"-\d\d": "", r"\W":""}, regex=True),
        is_math = lambda X: np.where(X['Course'].isin(is_math), True, False), 
        is_stats = lambda X: np.where(X['Course'].isin(is_stats), True, False), 
        is_major = lambda X: np.where(X['Course'].isin(is_major), 1, 0), 
        is_general_ed = lambda X: np.where(X['Course'].isin(is_general_ed), 1, 0)
        )
)


dat1.head()

title: Lesson 2: Reading Data
text:
Options to See Data:

view(): this opens a new tab to view the data in a spreadsheet style like Excel
head(): this returns the top six rows of a dataset, or the “head” of the data

title: Lesson 2: Reading Data
text:
Build-in Datasets
Run this code to see a list of built in datasets:

data()

The iris dataset is commonly used and built into R; no additional downloads are necessary.

view(iris)


head(iris)

title: Lesson 2: Reading Data
text:
Reading Data from URL
Read in this dataset from this URL: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv

housing_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")

head(housing_data)

title: Lesson 2: Reading Data
section: Reading Data from Local CSV File
text:
Reading Data from Local CSV File
First, let’s make a folder on your computer to use for bootcamp. I suggest putting it in your downloads folder or your documents folder and call it “R Bootcamp”.
Next, click the “Session” button at the top of RStudio, then “Set Working Directory”, then “Choose Directory” and use your computer’s file directory to navigate to the folder you made for bootcamp.
This set your “working directory” which basically makes it easier for us to deal with files.

Download the datasets.csv document to provide your answers to questions asked in the steps below.

title: Lesson 3: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
This lesson is focused on the first three wrangling verbs: select(), filter(), and mutate().
This will be our starting dataframe used in each of the examples below.

title: Lesson 3: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Selecting Columns
Syntax: select()
Think of it as selecting check boxes for each column to use. Any selected, whether it’s just one column or whether they’re many columns, will be available once this select() code is completed.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right where not all of the columns are needed, only the manufacturer, model, cty, and hwy columns. select() allows us to achieve this.









manufacturer
model
cty
hwy




audi
a4
18
29


audi
a4
21
29


audi
a4
20
31


audi
a4
21
30


audi
a4
16
26








Code Solution

mpg %>% 
    select(manufacturer, model, cty, hwy)

title: Lesson 3: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Filtering Rows
Syntax: filter()
Filtering is used in the scenarios like, “Only need students that are age 16 years old”, or “Only the the redwood trees in this forest that are taller than 30 ft”.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right where the cars are made by ford (manufacturer column) and the amount of highway miles per gallon is greater than 20 (hwy column). filter() allows allows us to achieve this.

model
displ
year
cyl

hwy

r
subcompact








Code Solution

mpg %>%
    filter(manufacturer == "ford", hwy > 20)







Operators to use in Filter Statements







Basic Operators:
> greater than
< less than
== equals
>= greater than or equal to
<= less than or equal to



Advace Operators
!= is not equal to
%in% c() is in

title: Lesson 3: First Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Making New Columns
Syntax: mutate()
Think of the mutate() verb as starting with one column and change it to where you want it to become–mutating a column. You can make new columns not based on columns, based on one column, or based on multiple columns.



Scenario
Say we want this dataframe to the right (make sure to scroll to see the other columns) where there was an error in the data and the city miles per gallon needs 5 more miles than what it currently had (cty column) and we need the a column for the engine displacement (displ column) divided by the number of cylinders (cylcolumn). In reality this second task is not a useful but we’re doing it for practice sake.

    mutate(cty = cty + 5, new_col = displ/cyl)

    mutate(real_charges = charges * 4)

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Before we do any exercises, make sure to run this code:
This is our dataset for this practice:

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Let’s learn about group_by() & summarise()
What if we want to learn:

the average BMI by gender
the total sum of charges by region in the US
min & max of children by  age

All of these are examples uses for group_by() and summarise() statements.

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Examples 1: Average BMI by Gender

dat %>% 
    group_by(sex) %>%
    summarise(Average_Age = mean(age)) 





sex
Average_Age

male
38.91716

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 1: Sum of Charges by Region
text:
Exercise 1: Sum of Charges by Region
Use the code below to get you started. Find the sum of the charges by region.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(______) %>% 
    summarise(_____________ = ___(_______))

Attempt the code above then use this dropdown for help


Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(Total_Charges = sum(charges))


This is the correct output:




region
Total_Charges




northeast
4343669


northwest
4035712


southeast
5363690


southwest
4012755

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 2: Min & Max of Children by Age
text:
Exercise 2: Min & Max of Children by Age
Use the code below to get you started. Find the minimum and maximum amount of children by age.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(___) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = ___(________),
        Max = ___(________)
        ) %>% 
    head()



Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(age) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = min(children),
        Max = max(children)
        ) %>% 
    head() 


This is the correct output:




age
Min
Max




18
0
4


19
0
5


20
0
5


21
0
4

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 3: Average Charges by Sex and by Smoker
text:
Exercise 3: Average Charges by Sex and by Smoker
Here no starter code is given. If you need to, look back at previous code chunks for guidence.
Try as best as possible to mimic the results below.
Only use the dropdown answer when you’ve tried as much as possible.


Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(sex, smoker) %>% 
    summarise(
        Average_Charges = mean(charges), 
        Total_Charges = sum(charges))

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
text:
Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
This dataset is bult into R so you already have it. It is called storms. This is a new dataset so you may want to either view() it or use the head() method on it.
Find the average and standard deviation of the wind speed and air pressure by storm category.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(category) %>% 
    summarise(
        mean(wind),
        sd(wind), 
        mean(pressure), 
        sd(pressure)
        ) %>% knitr::kable()


This is the correct output:

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
text:
Exercise 5: Summarizing by Month
Find the mean, median, and standard deviation of wind speed by month.
Only use the dropdown answer when you’ve tried as much as possible.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(month) %>% 
    summarise(
        Mean_Wind = mean(wind), 
        Median = median(wind), 
        St_Dev = sd(wind)
        )

title: Lesson 4: Last Three Wrangling Verbs
section: Exercise 6: Airquality Dataset - Summarising by Month
text:
Exercise 6: Airquality Dataset - Summarising by Month
This example is very similar to the previous example. This is a new datset and hopefully doing the same thing with another dataset will solidify the concept.
This dataset is bult into R so you already have it. It is called airquality. This is a new dataset so you may want to either view() it or use the head() method on it.


Answer
airquality %>% 
    group_by(Month) %>% 
    summarise(
        Mean_Wind = mean(Wind), 
        Median = median(Wind), 
        St_Dev = sd(Wind)
        )

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
text:
Data Used in examples below
library(tidyverse)

dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv")
The four main plots we will go over today:
What kinds of data do we have? In general, we have:

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
section: Histogram: Counting the Number of Numeric Occurances
text:
Histogram: Counting the Number of Numeric Occurances

X: Numeric, Y: N/A


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=bmi))+ 
   geom_histogram(bins = 50)+
    labs(
        title="Y-Axis Auto Counts the\n Occurances of Each Number",
        x="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
section: Bar Plot: Counting the Number of Categorical Occurances
text:
Bar Plot: Counting the Number of Categorical Occurances

Method 1: geom_bar()Method 2: geom_col()



X: Categorical, Y: Auto Counts Categories


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=region))+
    geom_bar()+
    labs(
        title="", 
        x="Categorical Column: 'region'", 
        y="Auto Counts the Occurances\n of Each Category")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))









X: Categorical, Y: Numeric


Code
plot_data <- dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(count = n()) 

ggplot(plot_data, aes(x=region, y=count))+
    geom_col()+
    labs(
        title="", 
        x="Categorical Column: 'region'", 
        y="Numeric Column: 'count'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
text:
Boxplot

X: Categorical, Y: Numeric


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=region, y=bmi))+
    geom_boxplot()+
    labs(x="Categorical Column: 'region'", y="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
text:
Scatterplot

X: Numeric, Y: Numeric


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x=age, y=bmi))+
    geom_point()+
    labs(x="Numeric Column: 'Age'", y="Numeric Column: 'bmi'")+
    theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold"))

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 1: Visualizing a Distribution using a Histogram
text:
Exercise 1: Visualizing a Distribution using a Histogram
Prompt: Show the distribution of math scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the `math score` column and make sure it is wrapped in tick marks. This is necessary when column names contain spaces.
use geom_histogram() on line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = `____ _____`))+ 
    geom____________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = `math score`))+ 
    geom_histogram()

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 2: Visualizing Counts of School Degrees
text:
Exercise 2: Visualizing Counts of School Degrees
Prompt: Make a bar chart visualizing the count of school degrees
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use parent_education column as the x axis
use geom_bar() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = ________________))+ 
    geom____________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = parent_education))+
    geom_bar()

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
section: Exercise 3: Scatter Plot to Visualize Test Scores
text:
Exercise 3: Scatter Plot to Visualize Test Scores
Prompt: Make a scatter plot visualizing the correlation of reading scores and writing scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the `reading score` column as the x axis
use the `writing score` column as the y axis
use the gender column as the color
use geom_point() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(data = ___, aes(x = `_______ _____`, y = _______________, color = ______))+
    geom________






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = `reading score`, y = `writing score`, color = gender))+
    geom_point()

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 4: Visualizing Distribution using Boxplots
Prompt: Make a scatter plot visualizing the correlation of reading scores and writing scores
Instructions:

use the dataset from above called bob
use the lunch column as the x axis
use the `math score` column as the y axis
use geom_histogram() in line 2

Starter Code:

ggplot(___, aes(_____, ____________))+ 
    geom__________

Notice in the starter code we didn’t specify data, x, and y. ggplot doesn’t require explicitly specifying the arguments for data, x-axis, and y-axis. Those are implied by their position in the code below. This way of writing code require less typing and is very common.





Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(bob, aes(lunch, `math score`))+ 
    geom_boxplot()



For the remainder of the exercises, no starter code is provided. Look back at previous exercises for help if needed.

title: Lesson 5: Graphing Part 1
text:
Exercise 5: Bar Chart
Prompt: Make a bar chart visualizing the types of lunches
Instructions:

Remake the plot below






Answer:


Code Solution
ggplot(data = bob, aes(x = lunch, fill = gender))+
    geom_bar()

text:

Remake the plot below

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
library(tidyverse)

dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv")

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
Labeling

labs()
Explanation
The labs() function is used to add label to the plot like the x-axis, the y-axis, and title.
Options:

title
subtitle

caption
x
y

Example


Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+
    geom_bar()+ 
    labs(title = "Counts of Regions", x = "Regions", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+ 
    theme_bw()

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
Faceting

facet_wrap() & facet_grid()
This of faceting as a third variable.

facet_wrap()








Code
ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+
            geom_bar()+ 
            facet_wrap(~sex)+
            labs(title = "Faceted Graph", x = "", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+
            theme(
                title = element_text(size = 20), 
                axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
                legend.title = element_text(size = 10), 
                legend.position = "none")

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
Themes
The following theme options affect all the non-data aspects

+ theme_bw()
+ theme_linedraw()
+ theme_light()
+ theme_dark()
+ theme_minimal()
+ theme_classic()
+ theme_void()
+ theme_test()

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
Coloring

Aesthetic
It is possible to set colors dynamically based on column of data or to set it as a static color.

fill and color inside aesthetic to a column of data
fill and color outside aesthetic to a static color

Setting colors dynamically and statically.
















More Examples for Better Understanding








Case 1
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), fill = "orange")

fill is set to ‘orange’ outside the aesthetic
color is not used

















Case 2
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), color = "black")

fill is not used
color is set to ‘black’ outside the aesthetic
















Case 3
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length), fill = "orange", color = "black")

fill is set to ‘orange’ outside of the aesthetic
color is set to ‘black’ outside of the aesthetic
















Case 4
You can do a combination of inside and outside of the aesthetic.
geom_bar(aes(x = Petal.Length, fill = Species), color = "black")

fill is set to ‘orange’ inside of the aesthetic
color is set to Species outside of the aesthetic. Notice this is a column in the dataset, not a static color.

title: Lesson 6: Graphing Part 2
text:
Scales


Code
ggplot(iris, aes(Petal.Width, Petal.Length, color = Species))+
  geom_point()+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 4, 1))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0,10,1))

ggplot(mpg, aes(class, fill = class))+
  geom_bar()+
  # scale_x_discrete(limits = c("2seater"))
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "blue", "red"))

# scale_x_continuous(
#   breaks = seq(15, 40, by = 5), 
#   labels = , 
#   limits = 
#   )

# scale_colour_brewer(palette = "Set1")

# scale_colour_manual(values = c(Republican = "red", Democratic = "blue"))

title: Reading Data
text:
The readr package is the first package that we will learn about. This allows us to read in rectangular data like cvs files.
This is the typical way it goes when you have data located on your computer.

library(tidyverse)

dataset <- read_csv(file_path)

head(dataset)

Copy the file path from your computer and paste it in the function. One downside to this is you have to manually replace each backslash \ with a forwardslash /
Here is an example:

library(tidyverse)

bob <- read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/US_Population_200_Years.csv")

head(bob)

# A tibble: 6 × 7
   Rank City             Population  Year PopDate    Longitude Latitude
  <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>
1     1 New York, NY          33131  1790 06/01/1790     -73.9     40.7
2     2 Philadelphia, PA      44096  1790 06/01/1790     -75.1     40.0
3     3 Boston, MA            18320  1790 06/01/1790     -71.1     42.3
4     4 Charleston, SC        16359  1790 06/01/1790     -80.0     32.8
5     5 Baltimore, MD         13503  1790 06/01/1790     -76.6     39.3
6     7 Salem, MA              7921  1790 06/01/1790     -70.9     42.5

title: Reading Data
text:
Method 2: “Import Dataset” Button Option
Another option is to use the “Import Dataset” button in the environment pane of RStudio.


The data will now be in your environment.

title: Reading Data
section: Method 3: Getting data from a URL
text:
Method 3: Getting data from a URL
Often you get your data from online somewhere like GitHub or Kaggle. While there is the option to download the file, then read it from your computer locally, like we just did above, there’s also the option to read in data from a URL.
A benefit is that less memory is used on your computer. Another is that you can send your analysis with the data being read in from a URL, and others will be able to run the script without any data issues.
Below is an example.

library(tidyverse)

data1 <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")

head(data1)

title: Reading Data
text:
Other Data File Formats
What if the dataset you have is not a csv? What if it’s an excel file or the often unused tsc?
Other options include:

read_excel() to read excel files like xls or xlsx
read_tsv() to read tsv files (tab separated files)
read_rds() to read RDS files (a data export option from SQLServer)

title: Reading Data
text:
Exceptions to the Norm
For most cases this is the way to read in data. There are some examples of variations.
Sometimes the column headers are not the top row of the data. In this scenario, use the option skip = 1 if there is one extra row above the headers.
Sometimes there are not column name at all and we’ll have to give them to the dataset. How can we do this?

title: Reading Data
text:
Writing Files
With readr, we can write data files.

write_csv(dataset_to_save, "file_name.csv")

title: Visualize Data
text: #ggplot

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text: Welcome to Data Science Society’s R Bootcamp

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text:
Course Outline:
The purpose of R Bootcamp is to be able to read, wrangle, and visualize data using R in RStudio. By the end of the course you will be able to contribute to a society project next semester.

Reading Data: readr package

navigating file systems
copy file paths
RStudio’s “Import Dataset” button, “From Text (readr)” option



Wrangling Data: dplyr/tidyr packages
Primary Focus: select, filter, mutate, groupby/summarise, and arrange.
Secondary Focus: joining, pivoting, case_when,
Other: drop_na(), replace_na(),


Visualizing Data: ggplot2 package

What kind of data these plot plot
code for each
histograms, boxplots, scatterplots, bar charts.

In Terms of Packages:

readr
dplyr/tidyr
ggplot

Others:

forcats (fct_reorder and working with factors)
stringr (working with text data)
lubridate (working with dates)
tibble (just the tibble() function)
purr (mappings, boring)

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
section: What kind of data are we using?
text:
What kind of data are we using?
We will mainly be using the _____ and the ____ datasets for practice.
What is data? Is it singular or plural?
What other types of data are there? Take this for example ____
We will be working with tabular data. Other data includes pictures, videos, and audio.
There are different types of data, we won’t get into the nitty-gritty parts of it, but there is structured, semi-structured, and ustructured data. We will be playing around with structured data (think excel files). Examples of the other types of data are pictures, video, and audio files.

readr: for data import
dplyr: for data manipulation
tidyr: for data tidying
ggplot2: for data visualisation
tibble: for tibbles, a modern re-imagining of data frames
stringr: for strings
forcats: for factors
purrr: for functional programming
+
lubridate: for dates

title: Wrangling Data
text:
Base R is the native tools that R has to deal with data. The syntax is outdated and better tools are available to use.
The syntax to work in Base R is very similar to native python syntax. The biggest downside is that it’s not possible to chain operations together like selecting columns and filtering data. You would to constantly assign and reassign variables which results in very messy and unreadable code.
If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don’t make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse.
Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required.




The Tidyverse allows chainable actions like this:

new_dataset <- dataset %>% 
    select() %>%
    filter() %>% 
    mutate() %>% 
    group_by() %>% 
    summarise() %>%
    arrange()

Run this code in the console to download the tidyverse

install.packages("tidyverse")

In order to be able to use this package, put this code at the top of your R Script or RMD file

library(tidyverse)











df$column_name
df[[]]





df %>% select(column1, column2)











df$profit <- df$revenue - df$cost





df %>% mutate(profit = revenue - cost)












df[df$temperature > 45]





df %>% filter(temperature > 45)











I’m not sure how to do this in BaseR… and that’s okay





df %>% 
    group_by(city) %>% 
    summarise(Avg_House_Price = mean(house_price))











mtcars[order(mpg, -cyl),]





mtcars %>% arrange(mpg, desc(cyl))





Check out this page for more comparisons.
Filtering Data in Base R:

https://www.mitchcraver.com/2021/06/15/subsetting-and-filtering-a-data-frame-in-r/
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/crunch/vignettes/filters.html

title: Lesson 1: Introduction & Installation
text:
Course Outline:
The purpose of R Bootcamp is to be able to read, wrangle, and visualize data using R in RStudio. By the end of the course you will be able to contribute to a society project next semester.

title: Lesson 1: Introduction & Installation
section: What is Data? Which Kind of Data Are We Going to Use?
text:
What is Data? Which Kind of Data Are We Going to Use?
We will be working with tabular data (think excel files; rows and columns). Other data includes pictures, videos, and audio.

title: Lesson 1: Introduction & Installation
text:
Click Here for Suplimental Videos


















The purpose of R Bootcamp is to be able to read, wrangle, and visualize data using R in RStudio. By the end of the course you will be able to contribute to a society project next semester.



navigating file systems
copy file paths
RStudio’s “Import Dataset” button




The Six Wrangling Verbs:

select()
filter()
mutate()
group_by()
summarise()
arrange()





When to use which plots: histograms, boxplots, scatterplots, & bar charts
code for each





We will be working with tabular data (think excel files; rows and columns). Other data includes pictures, videos, and audio.

library(tidyverse)
data1 <- read_csv("datasets/StudentsPerformance.csv")
# View(data1)


data2 <- data1 %>% 
    group_by(lunch, `race/ethnicity`) %>% 
    summarise("Avg Math" = mean(`math score`), "Std Math" = sd(`math score`))
view(data2)


ggplot(data2, aes())
